metadata.title: Avoidability of Additive Cubes over Alphabets of Four Numbers

body_text.text: In fact, using a symmetry argument we can improve the previous result.
We could improve this result with the same approach as the one we used in the proof of Theorem 3, but we already have a strong enough result for our purpose.
This set is obtained by taking the intersection of the sets of forbidden pairs from Theorem 3 and Theorem 4.
We use the fact that all but one of the remaining alphabets contain an alphabet equivalent to an alphabet from Theorem 6 or Theorem 7. Our main result after this reduction is the following:
We reformulate this result in terms of Problem 1.
Let us conclude by restating two remaining related open questions. First it is natural to ask whether additive cubes are avoidable over the only remaining alphabet (see Problem 7 in [8]).
It seems that additive cubes are avoidable over most alphabets of size 3. Our result might stimulate research to treat the following question.
Can we characterize the sets of integers of size 3 over which additive cubes are avoidable?
